ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Calculus and some related topics.

This course has definitely taught me the importance of thinking outside the box and development of critical thinking skills in order to solve the complex problems that were presented on the weekly psets. I developed a stronger knowledge of multivariable calculus and deeper appreciation for the subject of math.
Multivariable calculus

I developed familiarity with 3D space (in rectangular, cylindrical, and spherical coordinates) and an ability to visualize objects existing in 2D and 3D. Of course, I gained a solid foundation in multivariable calculus concepts including vectors, parametrization methods, line and surface integrals, and double and triple integrals.
break down complex problems across dimensions
I learned multivariable calc and different problem-solving techniques within the subject.
Graphical representations of shapes in 3d, connections between Calc BC and higher level multivariable, calculations of flux, calculations of areas under curves, etc.

MATH 120 provides a comprehensive introduction to Multivariable Calculus. I learned about a wide variety of topics, including vectors, equations of lines and planes, vector-valued functions, functions of 2 variables, partial derivatives, directional derivatives and gradient, tangent planes, maximum and minimum values, Lagrange multipliers, double integrals, triple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, curl and divergence, Green's Theorem, Stoke's Theorem, Divergence Theorem, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, and more.
I developed a better grasp on visualizing in 3D and using theorems to solve problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some topics are not given enough time.

The major strength of this course was the that it provided a good introduction to how Yale math department works as well as providing a solid foundation of multivariable calculus. The major weakness of this course was definitely the lengthy psets that sometimes felt tedious due to the difficulty, thus taking hours to complete.
Class section was great, wish there were more office hour times during the week.

The pre-class quizzes helped ensure that I was up to date on the material. However, the fact that those quizzes were weighted half the amount that Psets were seemed bizarre considering the time commitment that the Psets called for.

Strengths: MATH 120 is highly ordered and systematic, making it easy to consistently keep up with content and assignments. Modules (with their included pre-quizzes) and information on exams are all posted far in advance, allowing students to plan and budget their time each week. Plenty of resources are provided to help students succeed, including practice tests and Ximera. In my opinion, this course represents a very effective implementation of the "flipped classroom": the pre-lecture videos are well-paced and not too tedious.
Weaknesses: The lectures essentially cover the same content as the pre-lecture videos, and they tend to fall behind. Perhaps a format where lectures quickly review the content at the beginning and then spend most of the time working through practice problems would complement the pre-lecture videos better.
great organization; no significant weakness I think
I thought the course was well-taught and there were many resources to better understand the material, but it definitely required a lot of time to do so.
Having more peer tutors on the days prior to deadlines for homeworks can be helpful. Outside of that, I felt the course was well done.

MATH 120 has many strengths. Most importantly, there is an abundance of help, including peer tutor office hours (which were very helpful for problem sets), problem-solving sessions, professor office hours, and official review sessions for exams. I also felt that my professor, Danny Nackan, was very helpful in class teaching us material with packets and answering student questions.

My one possible complaint would be that a student's experience in MATH 120 could vary widely based on the professor they have. (And based on my experience in the Fall 2023 semester, it seems that there was a wide range in professor ability.)

Strengths:
I ultimately feel like I got a good grasp of calc
My instructor was good

Weaknesses:
P-sets serve a valuable function in learning, but too often they required mind-numbing integration which took a long time and was not related to any topic we were learning that week. I felt I spent more time doing integration than actually learning the concepts on the p-sets.
The homework serves little purpose if we are just going to learn the same thing in class.
I like rigor, but the weeks we had midterms we would have a p-set due Thursday of the previous week, then a p-set on that Monday, and then a midterm on Thursday.
It is too abstract and does not give you any sense of the utility of what you are learning.

Strengths: daily videos to explain concepts before class and review sessions before midterms. Weaknesses: exams, especially the final, felt rushed and as if they tested the most difficult versions of concepts, rather than the way problems were presented in problems sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would. It is very essential for any person with an interest in mathematics.

I would recommend this course to anyone required to take this course or are interested in studying math because of the foundation that it provides for higher level courses at Yale, but the workload for this course occasionally may bring unneeded stress and time commitment to do other activities.
yes
Yes; this course is valuable for a wide array of STEM fields, and it's honestly satisfying to see all the concepts you've learned from calculus classes so far come together.
Yes. Integral to any STEM-related majors.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in math as I enjoyed learning the subject matter and working through the problem sets really helped me to internalize the content. I would say it was pretty difficult and required a decent amount of commitment to really understand the content.

I'd recommend this course because I think it's a helpful introduction to college level math and what that entails. The principles themselves aren't too hard to grasp but the workload and independence the course demands are useful experiences to have.

I would recommend this course to any student who wishes to learn about Multivariable Calculus. The course is mainly theoretical, but it is nonetheless important as a pre-requisite to many STEM majors at Yale. The information you learn in this course will likely be used in future courses you take.
